docs.lead_paragraph: One thing you have to say about George W. Bush: he's got a great sense of humor. At a recent fund-raiser, according to The Associated Press, he described eliminating weapons of mass destruction from Iraq and ensuring the solvency of Medicare as some of his administration's accomplishments. Then came the punch line: ''I came to this office to solve problems and not pass them on to future presidents and future generations.'' He must have had them rolling in the aisles.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says recent good economic news does not change verdict that federal government is nowhere near solvent; asserts that Pres Bush governs like there is no tomorrow, launching war, increasing farm subsidies and establishing expensive new Medicare entitlement, while cutting taxes at same time; says some Republicans hope Bush is just doing whatever it takes to win next election and that he will then bring policy experts in; says he doubts that Bush people will have any idea of what to do when things fall apart (M)
docs.snippet: One thing you have to say about George W. Bush: he's got a great sense of humor. At a recent fund-raiser, according to The Associated Press, he described eliminating weapons of mass destruction from Iraq and ensuring the solvency of Medicare as some...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Life's Work column in the Job Market section on Nov. 23 described the consequences of the loss of a paycheck for a family. It cited the example of Janet Ray Kalson, who joined a strike against her employer, MFY Legal Services, in late October. The column attributed the strike to a loss of benefits like good health insurance and the right to family medical leave after MFY split off from a larger group, Legal Services of New York City. The column should have included a response from MFY Legal Services. It says that while there were changes in its benefit plan, it still offers good health insurance at no monthly cost to its employees. It also says it plans to offer medical leave, provided the union refrains from lobbying against financing for MFY, as it did in one case last spring.
docs.abstract: Editors' Note on Nov 23 Life's Work column describing consequences of loss of paycheck for family; article cited example of woman who joined strike against her employer, MFY Legal Services, and should have included response from that company

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''We Are Where We Shop,'' by Sharon Zukin (Op-Ed, Nov. 28): There is yet another element of the ''Faustian deal'' that Americans make when they shop at stores like Wal-Mart: the costs borne by the rest of us because Wal-Mart and, increasingly, similar large chain stores do not make affordable health care available to their employees.
docs.abstract: Prof Carole Joffe letter on Sharon Zukin's Nov 28 article holds failure of Wal-Mart and similar large chain stores to make affordable health care available to their employees passes on costs to taxpayers

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance plans that encourage Americans to use less expensive drugs may discourage some from taking important medications, researchers have found. When patients were forced to pay more for their medications under ''three-tiered'' prescription plans, they were more likely to stop taking the drugs, according to the study in the New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: National Briefing | Science and Health: Discouraging Drug Plan

docs.abstract: Study indicates that when patients are more likely to stop taking drugs if they are forced by health insurance plans to pay more for them under 'three-tiered' prescription plans (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A state judge has ruled that a new law requiring employers to provide contraception to women as part of health insurance coverage does not violate the free-exercise-of-religion clauses in the state and federal Constitutions. Church groups had challenged the law, saying it forced them to violate their beliefs by providing birth control to employees at hospitals and other institutions with religious affiliations. Dennis Poust, a spokesman for the New York State Catholic Conference, said the plaintiffs would appeal. Justice Dan Lamont of State Supreme Court ruled on Friday that state precedent going back to 1911 held that compelling government interests can permit some infringement on religious practice. The state's interest in providing necessary health care to women, Justice Lamont ruled, outweighed whatever First Amendment burden affected the religious charities. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Judge Clears Health Insurance Law

docs.abstract: Justice Dan Lamont rules that New York law requiring employers to provide contraception to women as part of health insurance coverage does not violate free-exercise of religion clauses of federal and state Constitutions, as claimed by church groups (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Latisha Singletary was shot and paralyzed from the waist down two years ago, there was an especially cruel irony to that life-changing moment. After all, she was the one who was supposed to help other people. She was the one who summoned the police in someone else's time of need.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Shot, Paralyzed and Raising Two Boys From a Wheelchair

docs.abstract: Arthur Bovino The Neediest Cases column discusses struggle of Harlem (NYC) woman Latisha Singletary to raise her sons after being shot and paralyzed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Japanese regulators formally took control of the Ashikaga Bank on Monday, the first regional bank Tokyo has nationalized. The step appeared to be an acknowledgement by the government that the longtime policy of nearly endless leniency and patience with deeply troubled financial institutions was not going to save them. The move came after a fresh round of government audits showed that the bank, which has 5.3 trillion yen ($48 billion) in assets, had far more problem loans than it had previously declared and that it was hopelessly insolvent. The bank was widely regarded as one of the weakest in the country.

headline.main: Japan Moves to Expand Cleanup of Banks

docs.lead_paragraph: Canadians and Americans still dress alike, talk alike, like the same books, television shows and movies, and trade more goods and services than ever before. But from gay marriage to drug use to church attendance, a chasm has opened up on social issues that go to the heart of fundamental values. A more distinctive Canadian identity -- one far more in line with European sensibilities -- is emerging and generating new frictions with the United States.

headline.main: Canada's View on Social Issues Is Opening Rifts With the U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Steffie Woolhandler, 52, an associate professor at Harvard Medical School and an internist at Cambridge Hospital, wants to change the health care system. Soon, and not in the way Congress just did. Her plan is simple. Get rid of the private health insurance industry and abolish Medicaid, the government's health insurance program for the poor. In their stead, set up a national health insurance system that would cover all Americans by expanding Medicare, the old-style Medicare, to include everyone from birth to death.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH: Steffie Woolhandler; Heal Health Care System? Start Anew

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Steffie Woolhandler, Harvard Medical School associate professor and Cambridge Hospital internist, discusses her plan to change US health care system and eliminate private insurance companies; plan is published in Journal of the American Medical Association; asserts that rising administrative costs are putting stranglehold on good health care; would abolish co-payments by patients; addresses rising drug costs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THREE years ago, Susan Sullivan, then 34, and her husband, Peter, 44, were thriving. The couple, both marketing professionals, worked hard and enjoyed a combined income of about $250,000 a year. Then, within two weeks of each other in the spring of 2001, the Sullivans lost their jobs, right about the time that she became pregnant. Unable to find work, they moved from Newton, Mass., a pricey Boston suburb, to Worcester, to cut their living expenses. With job prospects slim, they began entrepreneurial ventures: she, a marketing consulting firm, and he, a computer network security firm. Their daughter is now almost two. With combined yearly earnings of about $20,000, they have cut their spending to the bone and make ends meet with food stamps and credit cards.

headline.main: Economy & Business; The Pain of Coping When a Job Is Snatched Away

docs.abstract: Interviews with unemployed men and women in variety of careers, family situations and cities across nation suggest personal economic pain for those who have long been jobless will be long lasting, even as heavy reliance on credit and other factors has cushioned economy from impact of widespread joblessness; close look at household spending suggests muliplicity of ways, large and small, that rise in unemployment in past year or so has affected consumption patterns and economy; photos (M)
